Posts.Title: Help- Mom thinks I'm crazy? floridian floridian

Posts.Content: floridian wrote: Hi all - I know many of you are going through the same things that I am. I feel alternately paranoid and dismissive of the situation. I'm tired of being worried and sometimes want to just ignore my symptoms even though I know it is potentially dangerous. I am very high risk due to family history (mom) and other factors. I keep getting lumps and biopsies. Mom was very supportive and came up for my last surgery which was a large lump open excision. However, once I got a benign (pre-cancerous) result, she seems to think that I should just ignore the two lumps in my other breast and the fact that the previous diagnosis (fibroadenoma) did not match the birads 4 US. These things concern me and concerned a path friend of mine as well. The surgeon was going to try to get out any additional tissue by the clip with the excision but was unsuccessful and only took a large portion of the other lump. Now I feel like it's my duty to myself and my children and husband to follow up with a second opinion on that first questionable lump and the other two. My Mom says if I keep shopping doctors that someone will tell me what I want to hear. This made me mad! I asked her what exactly she thought I wanted to hear because all I want to hear is that I'm fine. Now, given, I don't want to someone to just pat me on the head and tell me I'm fine - I would like evidence that I'm fine. I would love it if they do the US and say -oh, don't worry, it's just simple cysts. I really don't want more surgery. The main problem for me is that the tests aren't really helpful due to density and I would like some reassurance without surgery. I don't know if it's possible. Am I just being paranoid? (dense breasts, fibroadenomas, duct ectasia, apocrine metaplasia and undiagnosed lumps) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Scared out of my mind! MN78 MN78

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 01:03PM floridian wrote: Hi - I think they usually try to use whatever mode by which they found the lump - there's no guarantee they'll even be able to see it with mammo. If they do use mammo - the wire localization uses less pressure than the regular one so it might not be as bad. I've had a D&C and an excisional biopsy separately and neither one was a huge deal (I was awake for both) so I would think if you can knock them both out while you are asleep that would be good. Try to relax yourself so you don't think too much about it and it will all be done before you know it. Make sure you know exactly what they are going to do beforehand (location of incisions, amount of tissue etc) so you don't have any surprises and then bring something distracting to the hospital like a video game, book etc so you don't get too worried and things will go smoother. Best wishes!

Posts.Title: Examples of Abnormal Mammos? floridian cs34

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 08:06PM floridian wrote: Hi -   Don't worry too much. The wire localization was no big deal. They used a mammo machine with a little window in it, took a film, developed it, came back and put the wire (tiny) in with local anesthesia and then confirmed with another mammo. You stay in the machine the whole time but they didn't compress as much as usual and the window helps. Also, they gave me a chair to sit in so it really wasn't that uncomfortable at all. I was awake for my surgery - a fairly sizeable lump at least in relation to the rest of me ;). I really had no pain at all. Just a little stinging. They gave me a vicoden after but I only nibbled at it and hid the rest in case I needed it which I didn't. I used lots of ice to keep the swelling and pain down - peas actually. Have several bags on hand. I was a little surprised by the core biopsy I had before and I think it was mostly that I was unprepared and didn't know what was going to happen so I hope this helps ease your mind. I took my iPod and played games on it while I was waiting for the surgery so I wouldn't think too much and chatted with my "neighbors". I read somewhere a study in which they gave gameboys to kids before surgery and they had much less pain. I really believe this. Bring something to distract you if you are a worrier like me.

Posts.Title: Ultrasound Prelim Results floridian floridian

Posts.Content: May 5, 2009 11:07AM floridian wrote: TFrye -  Here's something which may be helpful - A friend of mine is a retired renowned pathologist specializing in breast cancer. I had a birads 4 lesion for which I had core biopsy - very similar situation except yours is higher birads. The pathology report disagreed with the other tests. He recommended strongly that I have the entire biopsy material sent to another pathologist not associated with the company that did the first one and have a second opinion. I have yet to do this but I plan to. They did do a wire localization and excisional biopsy to try to get at this a second time but they missed so now I'm back to sending it out. From what I have read, there are three possibilities - one is that the path is right, two that they missed the spot, and three that there is malignancy but they sliced the wrong part. If they missed it, then you are back to square one - otherwise, getting a second opinion should tell the story as long as they are independent. I plan to try to get it sent without the report so I can get a clean opinion. Hope you get some answers that you can be confident in.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 07:27PM floridian wrote: Hi- I'm so sorry you are going through this. I have a hard time trusting doctors too mostly because three different ones will tell you three different things. It's so hard to sort out what is true and who to trust. I noticed you said one of the docs told you that the patient hardly ever finds the cancer but I'm pretty sure that is the opposite of the truth. I tend to trust the doctors who know the latest research, and whose statements match things that I know to be true and who listen to my concerns. My brother was born with Atrial Septal Defect and was tested repeatedly throughout his younger years to determine if it had closed. Now as an adult a cardiologist has convinced him that he never had ASD.  Of course he did have it, he just doesn't remember it and his new doc doesn't have access to the old tests. This seems similar to the statement about radiation in your case.  If you are concerned about it, pursue it and figure out who you trust. Unfortunately doctors are somtimes wrong - if three doctors give three different opinions about something, two of them are wrong. Sometimes too many opinions just confuse the issue. I'm sort of in a similar situation in which the surgeon wants to ignore the growing lumps. I'm seeing my OB/Gyn tomorrow whom I trust to see what she says. Best wishes,  Kim

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 12:11PM floridian wrote: Hi Everyone - I'm glad I found this thread - My Gail is 49% and my Gail plus is greater than 85%. I figure it's kind of like the rain prediction in Florida - if they say 50% that means it will rain 50% of the time. Since it's an all or none - you either have BC or you don't, it makes sense to me that if they say 50% they mean 50% of people with those characteristics will have BC and the others won't and they don't know which ones out of the population it will be. How many are out there that have the same problem I do - my breasts are so dense that mammos are useless and US and MRIs aren't much better? They did all three and couldn't see the large palpable lump they just took out. Surveillance doesn't seem to be much use. RE mastectomy: Does the recovery time depend on what type? Also, does it depend on what type of cancer? In other words, if I did a prophy, could I keep my skin and nipple and do immediate recon vs waiting to see if BC develops and then lose skin and nipple and have to do expanders etc? Plus maybe radiation so no recon? I'm not very well informed on this stuff and am hoping to learn more. If I keep having to get these lumps out surgically, I may want to opt for this. I've already had the nipple scraped on one side plus enough tissue out that my right breast is about 1/3 gone and completely different than the other. The nipples are now not at the same height. Although maybe if I wait and the new lump on the other side grows under the nipple as well, they will match - they will both look like volcanos with the tops blown off! Good thing I'm not that vain!

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 02:25PM floridian wrote: Hi Again - I just read the academic editorial about Gail. I think the difference between that and my thought process is that I'm not just worried about the next five years which looks like what they based the studies on. If you start from 1 out of 8 and then add family history, dense breasts, biopsies etc. you are likely to get higher than 50% for lifetime. I figure that if I'm going to get breast cancer at any time in my life, it may be better to have surgery done now to deal with it while my overall health is better than wait to deal with it under deteriorating health. I'm not there yet, but I'm guessing that's where I'm heading mentally. This stuff wears me out. Kim

Posts.Content: floridian wrote: Hi - I think I will post this both here and in the ILC section because I have thickening matching the symptoms posted there. I am hoping someone will be able to tell me if this seems OK or not. I had an open excision for a lump on Feb 24th so about a month ago. This was actually more like a thickening growing fast - probably quadrupled in about 3 months - turned out to be benign /  pre-cancerous on path- adenosis, fibrosis, duct ectasi, apocrine metaplasia. The surgeon apparently thought it looked cancerous during surgery because he marked the margins of one part and sent it for a frozen section. He did not take all of it and he did not get a previous lump they tried to locate with a wire which was birads 4 on core biopsy which they said was fibroadenoma but did not look like it on US. The lump was quite large and had grown under the nipple so he scraped the nipple and got a section about 2x2x1cm - but not all of it. Now I have a large hardened area well beyond the biopsied area. He took about 1/4 to 1/3 of my breast - I'm small. I had some discharge before and during the mammo wire procedure a lot of fluid sprayed out. I also had a lot of bleeding during the wire and after the surgery bled so much he wanted to take me back in - I managed to get it to slow down with pressure. Now I have stinging similar to milk letdown during nursing and new pain. I'm having more pain rather than less now. Is it possible that this is just the healing process? I guess that I'm worried that since he only took out part and didn't get the old bit that maybe the lump is still growing and that something is still there. Not really sure what to do about it anyway since I think they would disregard anything on imaging as scar tissue now. Any ideas? I know there is quite a lot of knowledgeable people here so please help! I was hoping to have clear answers after surgery but only have more questions.  Thanks! Posts.Content: floridian wrote: Hi all -  I had high hopes for my digital mammo today. I was there from 11am to 1:30 and walked away with no answers. I have an ultrasound scheduled also so they just brushed me off after waiting all that time and didn't want to let me meet with the radiologist. When I finally did, he just said to wait for the ultrasound and that nothing was really jumping out at him. I have very dense breasts so I had really pinned my hopes on this. I tried to get him to give me some indication of what all these lumps are but he didn't tell me a thing. I tried looking online for a mammo that looked like mine but I don't see any that look similar. Mine are filled with lines that are interconnected with star shaped spots. Has anyone had a digital mammo that showed anything useful? I'm mad because he just said wait for the ultrasound then I could get an MRI or biopsy. Why doesn't this guy get the fact that I don't want to be chopped on in 6 places? The point of having these tests is to determine the likelihood that it's cancer to avoid having to biopsy every lump. I don't want to wait until it "jumps out" and I really don't like it when they just refer me to the next test. They take no responsibility for using the test they just did to make any kind of determination. In the past I have had no luck - they do the mammo, US and MRI and then still do the biopsy. Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 05:16PM floridian wrote: Hello - Just had it done yesterday and feeling pretty good. Trying not to do too much so I don't start bleeding again but it doesn't even hurt. I had needle localization for an old lump under mammo and then that plus two more out yesterday - started early morning and was home by about 2:30. Would have been out sooner if I didn't start bleeding heavily - don't worry - we have a family bleeding problem. I was awake and it was really not that big a deal. I would definitely take the day off though because you might tear something open and they won't even let me take a shower until tomorrow. Oh - frozen peas work best. Get several bags and rotate and keep it on all the time. I didn't even need the pain meds. Oh - one other thing I think helped - I played games on my Ipod righ up until surgery so I was distracted and didn't have time to get nervous. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Excisional Biopsy hope09 floridian

Posts.Content: floridian wrote: About a year and half ago they found a level 4 "very suspicious" mass in my right breast near the nipple at 1 oclock. They did a core biopsy and said it was a fibroadenoma. This left a dent for a while. About 6 to 8 months ago, I felt a new lump (I couldn't feel the first one) in the same place which filled in the dent. I had US, MRI, Mammo - none could determine what it was apparently due to density in the area. They could not differentiate the lump from the very dense tissue there. I was referred to a surgeon who wanted to watch and wait for 3 months. I went back today - the lump is bigger and now has a finger like extension going under the nipple and it also feels like there is an additional lump on top. The surgeon now wants to do a needle localization in mammo to find the clip they put there before to remove anything left of the old lump and to take out the new lump in excision. He said that it "doesn't feel like cancer" to him but he said you can't be too careful especially with my Mom having double mastectomy at age 32. A pathologist friend told me previously that they should have another look at the lump if the diagnosis disagrees with the US and this was never done so this is part of what made me nervous when it grew back.  Has anyone had an experience like this? Particularly the finger like extension under the nipple? Anyone had a core biopsy and then regrowth?  Obviously I'm hoping it's just fibroadenoma but I don't know if they grow back or have extensions like this. I would rather be prepared for cancer if that's what it is. I do much better with preparing myself than surprises so if you have had a bad experience with something like this, don't mince words - just tell me flat out so I can start preparing. Of course, I would love it if someone told me it was normal too. :) (dense breasts, fibroadenomas, duct ectasia, apocrine metaplasia and undiagnosed lumps) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: had core now lump is back excision next floridian SandyL

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 06:21AM floridian wrote: I have very dense breasts and I just had some lumps out yesterday that they could not see on US, mammo or MRI. One was growing rapidly and I have another on the other side. The surgeon said about 30% of the time they can't see the lumps on anything! I was shocked. I felt like I was being very vigilant. My OB/GYN is a breast cancer survivor and she said do breast self exams all the time - not once a month. I think this is the right approach in addition to the other things because I found these lumps early and they only got big because the surgeon wanted to wait 3 months to follow up. Results today or tomorrow!

Posts.Title: had core now lump is back excision next floridian SandyL

Posts.Content: May 8, 2009 07:05PM floridian wrote: I have some similar problems so I can tell you what has happened with me. First I had a "thickening" above my nipple which was mildly painful and that's the only reason I noticed it. They did mammo (useless due to density) and an ultrasound. Didn't see anything. Did an MRI - didn't see anything. Sent to surgeon - he said wait 3 months. It quadrupled in size in that time and he did an excisional biopsy which was benign. Duct ectasia I think was the main cause which is in fact a blocked duct essentially. I now have a similar thing happening on the lower side below the nipple on the same breast which they are checking into. If you find out before I do, let me know and I'll do the same. I think you must be like me and not knowing is the worst part. It could be something like mine or different. If it's the same, supposedly warm compresses help- you could try that- I doubt it would hurt. At least this is one possibility. I hope this helps and perhaps you will get other opinions. I would definitely go see the doctor and find out what is going on.
Posts.Title: sorry to bother everyone kenziesmom22407 kenziesmom22407

Posts.Content: floridian wrote: Hello all -  Hope you are doing well after all your surgeries. I was hoping to start a topic here similar to the "What to Expect When You Are Expecting" idea (except of course, not fun). I found this to be extremely helpful when I was pregnant and it seems that many people are wondering exactly how the whole thing will go from the patient perspective. For example, exactly what happens? General Anesthesia, Mastectomy, Expanders vs Implants, What Are the Drains like and what comes out, how much pain and bruising, recovery time and limitations, reconstruction procedures and timing etc. I think this would be very enlightening for those of us to may be facing either necessary or prophylactic surgery. If there's already a thread like this, please direct me. Thanks so much for sharing your stories.   (dense breasts, fibroadenomas, duct ectasia, apocrine metaplasia and undiagnosed lumps) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 01:29PM floridian wrote: Thanks DDLatt - I looked at your flickr page and it made me cry. One of my sons is also named James. Your friends and family seem so sweet.  Maeve - thanks for sharing also. I can see how losing a part of your body you've been used to your whole life can be very traumatic. I keep telling myself I'm finished with them but it's hard to picture not having them. I'm even missing the chunks that are gone already. But they are not behaving themselves so they may have to go!
Posts.Title: What to expect with a Mastectomy? floridian tnmtnmomma

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 03:23PM floridian wrote: Hi Elisa -  I'm in the same situation right now. All I can tell you is that most things they find are benign. I been round and round with lumps etc. and they have found nothing cancerous. I just keep telling myself that it's not cancer till it's cancer. You can make yourself crazy with worry so it's best to try to focus on other things until you find out for sure. My Mom had BC when she was 32 and she's still fine right now at 64.  Best wishes!
